question:

Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

Which one of the following could be the schedule of the students' reports?
A) Mon. morning: Helen; Mon. afternoon: Robert Tues. morning: Olivia; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Lenore; Wed. afternoon: Kyle
B) Mon. morning: Irving; Mon. afternoon: Olivia Tues. morning: Helen; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Nina; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
C) Mon. morning: Lenore; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: George; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Robert; Wed. afternoon: Irving
D) Mon. morning: Nina; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: Robert; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Olivia; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
E) Mon. morning: Olivia; Mon. afternoon: Nina Tues. morning: Irving; Tues. afternoon: Helen Wed. morning: Kyle; Wed. afternoon: George
chain_of_thought: Nina's report triggers Helen and Irving's reports. George can only give a report on Tuesday. Olivia and Robert cannot give afternoon reports.  Consider the options and see which one fits the conditions.
full_output:
<think>Nina's report triggers Helen and Irving's reports. George can only give a report on Tuesday. Olivia and Robert cannot give afternoon reports.  Consider the options and see which one fits the conditions.</think>
<ans>B</ans>

The following restrictions apply: The guitarist does not perform the fourth solo. The percussionist performs a solo at some time before the keyboard player does. The keyboard player performs a solo at some time after the violinist does and at some time before the guitarist does. The saxophonist performs a solo at some time after either the percussionist does or the trumpeter does, but not both.

If the violinist performs the fourth solo, then each of the following must be true EXCEPT:
A) The percussionist performs a solo at some time before the violinist does.
B) The trumpeter performs a solo at some time before the violinist does.
C) The trumpeter performs a solo at some time before the guitarist does.
D) The saxophonist performs a solo at some time before the violinist does.
E) The trumpeter performs a solo at some time before the saxophonist does.
chain_of_thought: The violinist performs the fourth solo, so the guitarist doesn’t perform the fourth solo. The percussionist performs a solo before the keyboard player. The keyboard player performs after the violinist, and before the guitarist. The saxophonist performs after either the percussionist or the trumpeter, but not both.
full_output:
<think>The violinist performs the fourth solo, so the guitarist doesn’t perform the fourth solo. The percussionist performs a solo before the keyboard player. The keyboard player performs after the violinist, and before the guitarist. The saxophonist performs after either the percussionist or the trumpeter, but not both. </think>
<ans>E</ans>

question:
Four art historians—Farley, Garcia, Holden, and Jiang—will give a series of four public lectures, each lecture on a different topic—lithographs, oil paintings, sculptures, and watercolors. The lectures will be given one at a time, with each art historian giving a lecture on a different one of the topics. The schedule of the lectures is subject to the following constraints: The oil paintings lecture and the watercolors lecture must both be earlier than the lithographs lecture. Farley's lecture must be earlier than the oil paintings lecture. Holden's lecture must be earlier than both Garcia's lecture and Jiang's lecture.

Which one of the following is an acceptable ordering of the lectures, from first to fourth?
A) Farley: sculptures; Holden: lithographs; Garcia: oil paintings; Jiang: watercolors
B) Farley: watercolors; Jiang: oil paintings; Holden: sculptures; Garcia: lithographs
C) Garcia: sculptures; Farley: watercolors; Holden: oil paintings; Jiang: lithographs
D) Holden: oil paintings; Jiang: watercolors; Farley: lithographs; Garcia: sculptures
E) Holden: sculptures; Farley: watercolors; Jiang: oil paintings; Garcia: lithographs
chain_of_thought: Farley must lecture before the oil paintings lecture, and Holden must lecture before both Garcia and Jiang. We can deduce that the oil paintings lecture must be before the watercolors lecture, and the sculptures lecture must be before the lithographs lecture.  Only option B satisfies all the conditions.
full_output:
<think>Farley must lecture before the oil paintings lecture, and Holden must lecture before both Garcia and Jiang. We can deduce that the oil paintings lecture must be before the watercolors lecture, and the sculptures lecture must be before the lithographs lecture.  Only option B satisfies all the conditions.</think>
<ans>B</ans>

question:

The rugs must be woven according to the following rules: In any rug in which white is used, two other colors are also used. In any rug in which olive is used, peach is also used. Forest and turquoise are not used together in a rug. Peach and turquoise are not used together in a rug. Peach and yellow are not used together in a rug.

Which one of the following could be the colors of the three rugs?
A) forest only; turquoise only; olive, peach, and white
B) forest only; turquoise only; olive, peach, and yellow
C) peach only; turquoise only; forest, olive, and white
D) yellow only; forest and turquoise; olive and peach
E) yellow only; olive and peach; turquoise and white
chain_of_thought: We know that white must be used in two other colors, olive must be used with peach, and forest and turquoise are not used together. We also know that peach and turquoise are not used together and peach and yellow are not used together. We can use this information to deduce the possible combinations of colors.
full_output:
<think>We know that white must be used in two other colors, olive must be used with peach, and forest and turquoise are not used together. We also know that peach and turquoise are not used together and peach and yellow are not used together. We can use this information to deduce the possible combinations of colors.</think>
<ans>E</ans>

A) Silva University: Gonzalez, Lai Thorne University: Frost, Heideck, Mays
B) Silva University: Gonzalez, Mays Thorne University: Knutson, Lai
C) Silva University: Frost, Gonzalez, Heideck Thorne University: Knutson, Lai, Mays
D) Silva University: Frost, Heideck, Mays Thorne University: Gonzalez, Lai
E) Silva University: Frost, Heideck, Mays Thorne University: Gonzalez, Knutson, Lai
chain_of_thought: Frost and Heideck must be together, and if Lai and Mays are both assigned, they must be to different ceremonies. If Gonzalez is assigned to Silva, then Lai must be assigned to Thorne. If Knutson is not assigned to Thorne, then Heideck and Mays must be assigned to it. Combining all constraints, we can deduce that only option C satisfies all the conditions.
full_output:
<think>Frost and Heideck must be together, and if Lai and Mays are both assigned, they must be to different ceremonies. If Gonzalez is assigned to Silva, then Lai must be assigned to Thorne. If Knutson is not assigned to Thorne, then Heideck and Mays must be assigned to it. Combining all constraints, we can deduce that only option C satisfies all the conditions.</think>
<ans>C</ans>
